entry.title: Rant post: Shit will not work if you include Angular.js twice
entry.content: Alright I’m going to rant more than blog for this entry. I spent the last hour trying to find out why a library I’m planning to use (jquery-upload) didn’t work. I’ve learn that the asset pipeline is sort of a double edge sword…if you define something in the application and you define it again in your controller specific template, it will include the js file twice. Why isn’t Sprockets smarter?! Also, when I include AngularJS twice, subtle things stop working. Why can’t the AnglarJS guys not include the library if it detected that it’s already included??! Anyways end of rant. Back to work..

entry.title: Rails 3 redirect_to with flash :notice does not show up - problem.
entry.content:
I was working on my app just now and finally got rid of a stupid annoying thing – it wouldn’t update my flash messages for some reason after I do a redirect_to.

This was what I had:

Pretty standard stuff right? But for some reason I couldn’t get the flash messages working at all! I was so baffled by it but then I started tracing down the calls.

Turns out that the venues_path redirects to the index method, and in the index method it does a redirect to the edit method, and in Rails 3 you need flash.keep in order to preserve the flash message. Doh!
